# The dangerous distraction of to-do lists.

**“You just need to focus.”**

Steve Jobs used to say:

“People think focus means saying yes to the thing you’ve got to focus on. But that’s not what it means at all. It means saying no to the hundred other good ideas.”

This one speaks for itself.

It’s timeless advice, yet our minds love to complicate things.

It’s timeless advice, yet our minds love to complicate things.

So from today, say no to 99% of the ideas, suggestions and invitations, and you are off to a good start.

Jim Collins, the writer of the book Good to Great, suggested that instead of a to-do list, we should make a “Stop-doing list.”

How brilliant is that?

So, one day, I sat down with my pen and paper. And I’m telling you, it’s hard.

So, one day, I sat down with my pen and paper. And I’m telling you, it’s hard.

After months of trial and error, this is how I created a simple system that will also work for you.

Here we go:

1.  Set a timer for 10 minutes.
2.  Write down all your tasks.
3.  Order your list from most important to less important.  
    (Pro tip: Put money-making tasks above vanity-creating tasks.)
4.

Order your list from most important to less important.  
    (Pro tip: Put money-making tasks above vanity-creating tasks.)
4.  Now, take a red marker and cross out 3 and below.
5.  How do you feel? Liberated right. You left with 3 items that will move your business forward.
6.  Now, focus on each of the 3 goals until it’s done.

Do this, and you’ll become a focused executing machine that will crush procrastination.

# How to sell courses through email.

**If one thing keeps business owners up at night, it’s sales.**

You know the feeling when you’re at the dinner table, and your partner talks and talks about god knows what?

All you can do is stare and hear your thoughts like a broken record.

“How I’m going to make sales.” “How I’m going to make sales.” “How I’m going to make sales.”

The frustration of not knowing what to do next can bring a seasoned entrepreneur to his knees.

You can’t go back to your 9-5. The thought alone must fuel your motivation to make it work.

It’s time for social email selling.

Before we dive into email concepts, I like to give you an insight into how people buy.

Clients will buy on their terms, never on yours.

That means that you need to remind them often about your offer so they can justify the purchase.

In short, you must present your offer at least seven times before they consider buying.

The best way to do so is through email.

In short, you must present your offer at least seven times before they consider buying.

The best way to do so is through email.

The biggest mistake you can make is to bombard your audience with desperate sales messages.

When was the last time you bought shoes after a lousy sales attempt like this:

_“You have to be quick before they’re gone.”_

Never right?

So change your tune or get buried next to all those pushy, broke salespeople.

So change your tune or get buried next to all those pushy, broke salespeople.

So this is what you do instead:

*   Always share stories in your emails.
*   Make sure your emails are fun to read.
*   Add your personality; be yourself.
*   Give value and share the WHAT, never the HOW.
*   Always end with an offer.
*   Give clear instructions on how to move to the next step.
*   Send regular emails and always include a call to action.

*   Give clear instructions on how to move to the next step.
*   Send regular emails and always include a call to action.
*   Never be desperate or needy. (You’ll look silly.)

Sales don’t need to be a pain in the A\*\*. Interacting with your audience and making them low-key offers can be quite fun.

Show them that you don’t care if they buy or not.

Keep sending emails with offers, and over time, people will buy.
